key_insight: GPiCA introduces a compact hybrid representation that combines a triangle mesh for smooth surface regions with anisotropic 3D Gaussians for fine, view-dependent detail, enabling photorealistic head avatars that render efficiently on mobile devices.
problem_solved: How to produce and render photorealistic, multi-view-derived head avatars in real time on resource-constrained devices without huge memory or compute costs.
method: Reconstruct a triangle mesh for large, smooth facial surfaces and fit anisotropic 3D Gaussians to capture fine-scale, view-dependent appearance (hair, eyes, speculars, soft geometry).
Jointly optimize geometry and Gaussian attributes from multi-view images, then use a hybrid renderer that rasterizes the mesh and blends Gaussian primitives for detailed shading.
Design the representation and rendering pipeline for low memory footprint and GPU-friendly execution suitable for mobile real-time rendering.
impact: GPiCA enables high-quality, real-time avatar rendering on mobile/edge devices, lowering barriers for AR/VR, telepresence, and interactive applications by balancing photorealism with practical memory and performance constraints.
visual_elements: Side-by-side schematic of the hybrid representation: triangle mesh overlayed with colored anisotropic 3D Gaussians highlighting different roles.
Pipeline flowchart from multi-view capture → joint optimization → hybrid rendering, annotated with compute/memory advantages.
Comparison grid showing visual quality vs. rendering time/memory for GPiCA versus mesh-only and Gaussian-only baselines.
Zoomed detail panels (hair, eyes, specular highlights) demonstrating how Gaussians capture fine, view-dependent effects.
paper_title: Gaussian Pixel Codec Avatars: A Hybrid Representation for Efficient Rendering
paper_authors: Divam Gupta, Anuj Pahuja, Nemanja Bartolovic, Tomas Simon, Forrest Iandola
